sen.j: 建部山城（たけべやまじょう）は丹後国加佐郡（現在の京都府舞鶴市下福井）にあった室町時代から戦国時代にあった城。
sen.e: Takebeyama-jo Castle existed in Kasa Ward of Tango no Kuni (now Shimofukui, Maizuru City, Kyoto Prefecture) during Muromachi Period and Sengoku Period.
Takebeyama-jo Castle existed in Kasa Ward in Tango no Kuni (now Shimofukui, Maizuru City, Kyoto Prefecture) during the Muromachi and Sengoku Periods.
sen.cmt: 「of」→「in」, 「Muromachi Period and Sengoku Period」→「the Muromachi and Sengoku Periods」
sen.e: Takebeyama-jo Castle existed in Kasa County, Tango Province (now Shimofukui, Maizuru City, Kyoto Prefecture) during the Muromachi and Sengoku periods (period of warring states).
sen.cmt: Kasa County, Tango Province としました。戦国時代の補足を追加しました。

sen.j: 室町時代に栄えた守護大名・一色氏の根拠地。
sen.e: It was a base of the Isshiki clan who was a Shugo-Daimyo (a feudal lord that has grown from a military governor (shugo)) and thrived in Muromachi Period.
It was a base of the Isshiki clan who were Shugo-Daimyo (feudal lords who were previously military governors or 'shugo') and thrived during the Muromachi Period.
sen.cmt: Changed to plural. 「that has grown from a」→「who were previously」, double parentheses avoided by use of inverted commas.
sen.e: It was a base of the Isshiki clan who were Shugo-Daimyo (feudal lords who were previously military governors or 'shugo') and thrived during the Muromachi period.
sen.cmt: period 小文字にしました。

sen.j: 南北朝時代の1336年（建武3）に南朝に味方した豪族によって築城されたと伝えられる。
sen.e: This castle was built in 1336 by a local powerful family who supported Nancho (the Southern Emperor's forces) in Nanbokucho Period (or Northern and Southern Courts Period during which there existed a Northern Imperial Court and Southern Imperial Court in the north and the south of Kyoto-Nara area, respectively, claiming their own sovereignty).

This castle was built in 1336 by a powerful local family who supported Nancho (the Southern Emperor's forces) in the Nanbokucho Period (or the Northern and Southern Courts Period, during which there existed a Northern Imperial Court and Southern Imperial Court in the north and the south of the Kyoto-Nara area, each claiming their own sovereignty).
sen.cmt: 「local powerful」→「powerful local」, 「the」挿入x3,「,」挿入,「respectively,」→「each」,
sen.e: This castle was built in 1336 by a powerful local family who supported Nancho (the Southern Emperor's forces) in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts.
sen.cmt: 南北朝時代の補足を統一しました。the Nanbokucho period (the period of Northern and Southern Courts)→the period of the Northern and Southern Courtsに変更しました。

sen.j: 観応の擾乱の時に足利氏軍によって攻撃され、北朝側の拠点になった。
sen.e: At the time of Kanno no Joran (the internal battles of Ashikaga Shogunate that lasted for a few years in the mid 14th century), Ashikaga clan' army attacked this castle, and it was turned to a base of Hokucho supporters (the Northern Emperor's force).

At the time of Kanno no Joran (the internal battles of the Ashikaga Shogunate that lasted for several years in the mid 14th century), the army of the Ashikaga clan attacked this castle, and it became a base for Hokucho supporters (the Northern Emperor's force).
sen.cmt: 「the」挿入, 「a few」→「several」, 「Ashikaga clan' army」→「the army of the Ashikaga clan」,「was turned to」→「became」, 「of」→「for」,
sen.e: At the time of Kanno Disturbance (the internal battles of the Ashikaga Shogunate that lasted for several years in the mid 14th century), the army of the Ashikaga clan attacked this castle, and it became a base for Hokucho supporters (the Northern Emperor's force).
sen.cmt: Kanno Disturbance としました。

sen.j: まもなく丹後国の守護として足利氏の側近であった一色範光が入ると、建部山城を居城とした。
sen.e: Before long, Norimitsu ISSHIKI, a Shugo (hereditary military constable that occupied provincial military and civil supervisory posts mainly in the 13th and 14th century) of Tango no kuni and a close aide to Ashikaga clan, obtained this castle to make his base of it.

Before long, Norimitsu ISSHIKI, a Shugo (a hereditary military constable who occupied provincial military and civil supervisory posts mainly in the 13th and 14th century) of Tango no kuni and a close aide to the Ashikaga clan, obtained this castle to make it his base.
sen.cmt: 「a」挿入, 「the」挿入, 「his base of it」→「it his base」
sen.e: Before long, Norimitsu ISSHIKI, a Shugo (provincial constable) of Tango Province and a close aide to the Ashikaga clan, obtained this castle to make it his base.
sen.cmt: Shugo (provincial constable), Tango Provinceとしました。

sen.j: その後は代々一色氏の居城としてつづいたが、1579年（天正7）に織田信長の命を受けた細川幽斎が丹後を攻撃、各地で敗れた一色軍は建部山城に篭城するが細川軍の猛攻の前に崩壊する。
sen.e: After that, the Isshiki clan had kept Takebeyama-jo Castle for some generations until 1579 when Yusai HOSOKAWA attacked Tango by order of Nobunaga ODA, and the Isshiki army barricaded themselves in this castle after losing every battle, but eventually fell through under Hosokawa army's fierce attack.

After that, the Isshiki clan held Takebeyama-jo Castle for several generations until 1579 when Yusai HOSOKAWA attacked Tango under the orders of Nobunaga ODA, and the Isshiki army barricaded themselves in the castle after losing each battle fought, but eventually fell under the Hosokawa army's fierce attack.
sen.cmt: 「had kept」→「held」, 「some」→「several」,「by order」→「under the orders」, 「this」→「the」,「every battle」→「each battle fought」, 「through」削除, 「the」挿入
sen.e: After that, the Isshiki clan held Takebeyama-jo Castle for several generations until 1579 when Yusai HOSOKAWA attacked Tango under the orders of Nobunaga ODA, and the Isshiki army barricaded themselves in the castle after losing each battle fought, but eventually fell under the Hosokawa army's fierce attack.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 『一色軍記』によれば、細川軍に敗れた丹後守護一色義道は、近くの中山城（舞鶴市）に逃亡したが、同城主 中山幸兵衛の裏切りにより自害した。
sen.e: According to "Isshiki Gunki" (Isshiki family's military history book), Tango's Shugo Yoshimichi ISSHIKI, defeated by the Hosokawa army, escaped to nearby Nakayama-jo Castle (Maizuru City), but he had to kill himself because of the castle's lord Kobee NAKAYAMA's betrayal.

sen.cmt: 「the」挿入, 「in」挿入, 「because of」→「due to」, 「betrayal」箇所異動
sen.e: According to "Isshiki Gunki" (the Isshiki family's military history book), Tango's Shugo Yoshimichi ISSHIKI, defeated by the Hosokawa army, escaped to nearby Nakayama-jo Castle (Maizuru City), but he had to kill himself due to the betrayal of the castle's lord, Kobee NAKAYAMA.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: その後、信長より丹後統治を任された細川藤孝は、本拠を良港を抱える宮津城とする一方、加佐郡における拠点として、平地部に田辺城を築城したために、建部山城は廃城となった。
sen.e: Later, ordered by Nobunaga to govern Tango, Fujitaka (Yusai) HOSOKAWA based himself in Miyazu-jo Castle that controlled a good port, and built Tanabe-jo Castle in a level land Tanabe as a base in Kasa Ward, abandoning Takebeyama-jo Castle.

Later, ordered by Nobunaga to govern Tango, Fujitaka (Yusai) HOSOKAWA based himself in Miyazu-jo Castle, which controlled a good port, and built Tanabe-jo Castle on level land in Kasa Ward, abandoning Takebeyama-jo Castle.
sen.cmt: 「that」→「, which」, 「in a」→「on」,「Tanabe as a base」削除
sen.e: Later, ordered by Nobunaga to govern Tango, Fujitaka (Yusai) HOSOKAWA based himself in Miyazu-jo Castle, which controlled a good port, and built Tanabe-jo Castle on level land in Kasa County, abandoning Takebeyama-jo Castle.
sen.cmt: Kasa County としました。

sen.e: There are some remains of it.
Some parts remain visible today.
sen.cmt: 再構成しました

sen.j: 建部山自体が標高315メートルと周囲の山よりもやや高く、同時に「田辺富士」「丹後富士」と呼ばれる優美な形をした山であり、加えて山頂から眺める舞鶴湾などの景色が絶景であるため、地元民のハイキングスポットとなっている。
sen.e: Since Takebe Mountain that the castle was seated on, called 'Tanabe Fuji' or 'Tango Fuji' because of its elegant shape, is a bit higher than other mountains around with 315 m in height above sea level, and also is blessed with a great view of Maizuru Bay from its top, local people enjoy hiking there.

Since Takebe Mountain where the castle was located, called 'Tanabe Fuji' or 'Tango Fuji' because of its elegant shape, is a bit higher than other mountains nearby, having a height of 315m above sea level, local people enjoy hiking there, taking in the great view of Maizuru Bay from the top.
sen.cmt: 再構成しました
sen.e: Since Mt. Takebe where the castle was located, called 'Tanabe Fuji' or 'Tango Fuji' because of its elegant shape, is a bit higher than other mountains nearby, having a height of 315 meters above sea level, local people enjoy hiking there, taking in the great view of Maizuru Bay from the top.
sen.cmt: 二バイト文字を修正しました。Mt. Takebe としました。

sen.j: また、山頂には旧陸軍の砲台跡なども残っており、近代史の探訪も兼ねることができる。
sen.e: A remain of a gun battery of the Imperial Army of Japan on the mountaintop tells a bit of Japan's modern history.

sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.e: This mountain is now commonly called 'Takebe-san.'
